dataset.title: Abundance of eukaryote picophytoplankton from a moored submersible flow cytometer at Martha's Vineyard Coastal Observatory, ongoing since 2003

abstract.para: This is a 16-year time series of the abundance of eukaryote picophytoplankton at 4 meters depth at the Martha's Vineyard Coastal Observatory, about 3 km south of Katama Beach, Edgartown, Massachusetts, USA. Picophytoplankton were sensed in situ by a submersible flow cytometer (FlowCytobot, or FCB). Sampling frequency was continuous at approximately 20-minute intervals binned to hourly resolution with some exceptions (e.g., winter in some years). For years 2003, 2004, and 2006, this dataset is a new version of previously published data available in NOAA NCEI.

keywordSet.keywordThesaurus: SeaDataCloud Flow Cytometry Standardised Cluster Names

additionalInfo.para: In the next version of this data package we may consider adding columns for scientificName Eukaryota and scientificNameID urn:lsid:algaebase.org:taxname:86701

description.para: Data were acquired by a moored submersible flow cytometer (FlowCytobot, or FCB) that was mounted on the offshore tower at Martha's Vineyard Coastal Observatory. Sampling frequency was continuous at approximately 20-minute intervals with some exceptions (e.g., approx. 4 mos at the beginning of 2004, 2005, and 2006, August 2007, December 2008, February and October 2014, approx. 3 mos at the beginning of 2015 and 2017, and February 2016). The FCB (described by Olson et al., 2003, https://doi.org/10.1016/S0967-0637(03)00003-7) is used to count cells for populations of photoautotrophs (Synechococcus and picoeukaryotes). The FCB automatically runs bead samples approximately once per day. Data for Synechococcus are available elsewhere (Hunter-Cevera et al., 2017, https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.jm8s7). Data for picoeukaryotes include small eukaryotes that exceed the typical picoplankton size, consistent with the definition that cell cycle within this group may generate cells with size greater than 2 microns (http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/F02/current/F0200004/).

Data processing involved classifying observations as eukaryote picoplankton based on their scattering and fluorescence signatures, calculating concentrations based on the volume of water sampled at each time point, and binning to hourly resolution with code available in GitHub: https://github.com/hsosik/NES-LTER/tree/master/fcb_processing. Time of sampling needed to be corrected from local to UTC for some of the early years in the time series. Data for the entire time series were processed; thus, for years 2003, 2004, and 2006, this dataset is a new version of data previously published by Robert J. Olson, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (2010) available in NOAA NCEI Oceanographic Data Archive: NODC Accession 0002299, NODC Accession 0002722, NODC Accession 0036656. These data serve as input to a division rate model by Fowler et al., 2020, http://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3708062. These data serve as the raw data for the derived data products in Fowler et al., 2020, https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1918439117.
# Additional data cleaning and quality assurance

Additional data cleaning and metadata template assembly to align with SeaDataCloud SDN data management protocols for Flow Cytometer data were performed with code available on GitHub: https://github.com/WHOIGit/nes-lter-picoeuk-mvco. We added attributes to provide spatial context to the data table and assured that the temporal coverage and values for cell concentration were within expected ranges.

abstract.para: The Northeast U.S. Shelf (NES) Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) project integrates observations, experiments, and models to understand and predict how planktonic food webs are changing, and how those changes impact the productivity of higher trophic levels. The NES-LTER is co-located with the Northeast U.S. Continental Shelf Large Marine Ecosystem, spanning the Middle Atlantic Bight and Gulf of Maine. Our focal cross-shelf transect extends about 150 km southward from Marthaâ€™s Vineyard, MA, to just beyond the shelf break. Our overarching question is: How is climate change impacting the pelagic NES ecosystem and, in particular, affecting the relationship between compositional (e.g., species diversity and size structure) and aggregate (e.g., rates of primary production, and transfer of energy to important forage fish species) variability?

dataTable.entityDescription: Data table with eukaryote picophytoplankton cell concentration and time sampled

attribute.attributeDefinition: date and time in UTC for the sampling event http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/eventDate
abundance per unit volume of eukaryote picophytoplankton http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P01/current/SDBIOL01/ http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/F02/current/F0200004/
depth of sample below sea surface http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P09/current/DEPH/
